strategy: Implement a stacking ensemble with Random Forests as meta-model.

actions.action:
cat << 'ENDOFFILE' > train_and_predict.py
import pandas as pd
from sklearn.model_selection import KFold
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestRegressor, StackingRegressor
from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression
from sklearn.metrics import mean_squared_error
from sklearn.preprocessing import StandardScaler

# Load data
train = pd.read_csv('data/train.csv')
test = pd.read_csv('data/test.csv')

# Drop rows with missing target value
train.dropna(subset=['SalePrice'], inplace=True)

# Combine train and test sets for preprocessing
combined = pd.concat([train.drop(columns='SalePrice'), test], axis=0)

# Fill numerical NaNs with median
numerical_cols = combined.select_dtypes(include=[float, int]).columns
combined[numerical_cols] = combined[numerical_cols].fillna(combined[numerical_cols].median())

# Convert categorical variables to dummy variables
combined = pd.get_dummies(combined)

# Split back into train and test sets
X_train = combined.iloc[:len(train)]
X_test = combined.iloc[len(train):]

# Define base estimators
base_estimators = [
    ('rf', RandomForestRegressor(n_estimators=100, random_state=42)),
    ('lr', LinearRegression())
]

# Define meta-estimator
meta_estimator = LinearRegression()

# Create stacker
stacker = StackingRegressor(estimators=base_estimators, final_estimator=meta_estimator)

# Scale features
scaler = StandardScaler()
X_train_scaled = scaler.fit_transform(X_train)
X_test_scaled = scaler.transform(X_test)

# Train stacker
stacker.fit(X_train_scaled, train['SalePrice'])

# Predict on test set
y_pred = stacker.predict(X_test_scaled)

# Prepare submission
submission = pd.DataFrame({'Id': test['Id'], 'SalePrice': y_pred})
submission.to_csv('submission.csv', index=False)

ENDOFFILE
